text: I follow her anyway. The night wind clears my head instead—clear enough for me to realize I don’t actually know what I’m chasing.
She walks fast. Afraid of losing her, I unconsciously quicken my steps. My heel snaps against an icy stone tile with a sharp crack.
Alicia’s silhouette freezes. The pause is brief—but it feels like a blade pressed to my throat.
“Do you want to die?”
“I—I was just afraid of losing you.”
She doesn’t turn around, but her fingers shift slightly beneath her cloak. The next second, a low laugh slips out of the shadows at the end of the alley.
Someone’s there. Someone really is watching us.
My stomach drops. I try to step back—and hit a length of iron chain buried under snow. It rattles, sharp and brittle.
In that instant, the darkness in the alley seems to come alive.
“…Tch.”
She turns. Her eyes are terrifyingly bright—like a beast cornered against a wall.
“Didn’t I tell you I want you alive?”
“I wasn’t trying to slow you down—”
A black-robed figure lunges out of the alley mouth, something like a talisman clenched in their hand.
I react on instinct, starting to draw my blade—but before I can—Alicia is already in front of me.
The movement isn’t protection so much as possession. She folds me completely into the shadow of her cloak, as if even the wind isn’t allowed to touch me.
“Don’t look at him.”
Her sword leaves its sheath without a sound. In the next heartbeat, the black-robed man’s wrist is severed, the talisman fluttering into the snow.
He tries to scream. She kicks upward—snow and blood choke the sound off together.
When it’s over, she hasn’t even started breathing harder. She turns to me, but the agitation in her eyes looks like it could burn straight through me.
“I won’t let anyone hurt you again.”
“This time—I protected you too.”
She says it too fast, too hard—like she’s swearing it to herself.
“Calm down… I’m fine.”
The corner of her mouth twitches—half a smile, half pain.
“Of course you’re fine.”
“Because I’m here.”
She grabs my wrist. Hard enough to make my arm go numb. It’s not pulling—it’s dragging.
“From now on, you only need to do one thing.”
“Stay where I can see you.”
She picks up the snow-soaked talisman, crushes it in her fist, and shoves it into her coat—like biting down on a problem until it breaks.
“Move. Next stop.”
